The sequencing of the dog genome in the 1940s, or "dogenome," as they called it back then, would require euthanizing 300 dogs, they estimated, as they would take the DNA of each dog cell to try to sequence, in order to have enough copies. It was aborted when they had euthanized 25 dogs, as they were still not being able to extract enough dog DNA (or DogNA as they've nicknamed it), sequencing less than one fourth of what they were expecting to achieve with 25 dogs, which mean that the total number of dogs required would be more than 1200. To make things worse, they were considering using puppies, which, despite having less cells, have fresher DNA that's best to sequence, and then to compensate for the smaller size of puppies they'd need to increase the number proportionately to the bodyweight of adult dogs, requiring something like 8000 puppies. That was unacceptable, and the experiment stopped.

I was just wondering, but what happens after PCR? Like how do they detect the presence of viral DNA? I would assume they would use a complementary strand of the viral genome and if it binds with the DNA from the PCR, then some sort of indicator would allow scientists to know.

Also, noteworthy, thanks to PCR you don't need to isolate Taq polymerase from T. aquaticus any more. You just take the gene for that polymerase, put it into E. coli~and isolate from there. (and when you're at it, change the "genetic construct" so that protein is made in a huge amount; unlike in... T. aquaticus,). There, no need for having a geyser inside a lab!

There's also the problem with unspecific amplification at low temperatures, which means that there is a chance for the primers to bind at any non-matching DNA strand if the temperature is low enough, like during the period where you mix all the PCR ingredients and heat it up for the first time. Now, normally you would just mix it on ice with the polymerase as last ingredient to prohibit the polymerase from doing anything, but there's also another way.
So they invented hot-start polymerase. It's basically a normal polymerase, but a specific antibody is blocking the active center, rendering the enzyme inactive. However, the antibody is from a mammal, so it doesn't withstand the high temperatures the polymerase needs to work properly. Now, you can just mix everything at room temperature and heat it up, as the antibody will denature at about 45-60°C, open up the active center and starting the polymerase at the perfect temperature.

Recently, I learnt it and did PCR  and then gel electrophoresis to evaluate the result.The machine that we use for PCR is actually called thermal Cycler. For detecting the viral genome of SARS-CoV-2(having RNA genome), they usually perform qRT-PCR(quantitative Real Time PCR). In qRT-PCR,RNA is converted to cDNA by using an enzyme called reverse transcriptase and then qPCR is performed. In qPCR, we also add a specific flourescent dye(and also primers,PCR buffer),as the DNA gets amplified we can corelate it with the detected level of flourescence. Then, based on the Ct value(the no. Of cycles the sample(target cDNA) requires to cross the threshold), we can confirm the presence or absence of the virus which causes COVID-19.

Since the title talked about a virus I thought there was going to be a bit on reverse transcriptase (RT) as an explanation of how RT-PCR works. Kind of sad, but still a good video.
(Just in case someone is curious the RT enzyme makes a DNA based copy of a stand of RNA, then you can take the cDNA make it go kissy kissy with the PCR enzyme and boom you have a bunch nucleotides that match your initial RNA but the Uracil is replaced by Thymine. Of course if the virus RNA you were looking for wasn't in the initial sample then you won't have a bunch of DNA because your primers wont attach, therefore the test is negative.)

Kary Banks Mullis (December 28, 1944 – August 7, 2019) was an American biochemist. In recognition of his invention of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technique, he shared the 1993 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Michael Smith and was awarded the Japan Prize in the same year. His invention became a central technique in biochemistry and molecular biology.
